set1.title: Present Perfect Simple vs Continuous – Set 1
set1.summary: The present perfect simple highlights finished actions, results, and how many/how much, and is usually used with stative verbs like 'know', 'love', and 'have'. The present perfect continuous focuses on the duration or repetition of an activity and often explains a recent or visible effect now. With dynamic verbs, both forms are sometimes possible, but the continuous stresses the activity itself, while the simple stresses the result or completion.

questions.question:
1. Fill in the blank (duration/how long – continuous)
I'm sorry I'm late. I ____ (wait) for the train for almost an hour.
questions.explanation: We focus on how long the action has been in progress, so we use the present perfect continuous.

questions.question:
2. Fill in the blank (completion/how many – simple)
She ____ (read) five books so far this summer.
questions.explanation: We focus on the number of completed actions (how many books), so we use the present perfect simple.

questions.question:
3. Fill in the blank (recent effect – continuous)
Your hair is wet. ____ you ____ (run) in the rain?
questions.explanation: We explain a visible present result (wet hair) caused by a recent ongoing activity, so we use the present perfect continuous.

questions.question:
4. Fill in the blank (stative verb – simple)
I ____ (know) him since we started high school.
questions.explanation: With stative verbs like 'know', we normally use the present perfect simple, not the continuous.

questions.question:
5. Fill in the blank (negative, duration – continuous)
They ____ (not sleep) well lately because of the noisy neighbours.
questions.explanation: We talk about an ongoing situation 'lately' and its effect now, so we use the present perfect continuous.

questions.question:
6. Multiple choice (result vs activity)
I'm not hungry. I ____ already ____ breakfast.
questions.explanation: We focus on the finished action and its result (I'm not hungry now), so we use the present perfect simple.

questions.question:
7. Multiple choice (duration vs result)
Ben ____ at this company for ten years, but he ____ three different positions.

options.b: has been working / has been having

questions.explanation: Both verbs refer to long-term states, so we use the present perfect simple to describe his experience and completed changes.

questions.question:
8. Multiple choice (recent effect – continuous)
Why are your hands so dirty?
Because I ____ the bike.
questions.explanation: We explain a visible present effect (dirty hands) caused by a recent ongoing activity, so we use the present perfect continuous.

questions.question:
9. Error correction (stative verb)
Wrong sentence: 'I have been loving this new series since the first episode.'
Correct the sentence.
answers: i have loved this new series since the first episode.
i have loved this new series since the first episode
have loved this new series since the first episode.
have loved this new series since the first episode
I have loved this new series since the first episode.
I have loved this new series since the first episode
questions.explanation: 'Love' is a stative verb, so we use the present perfect simple, not the continuous.

questions.question:
10. Choose the best sentence (duration vs result)
You see your friend, who looks very tired. Which sentence is more natural?

options.a: I see you're tired. How long have you worked today?
options.b: I see you're tired. How long have you been working today?
options.c: I see you're tired. How long did you work today?
options.d: I see you're tired. For how long you work today?

questions.explanation: We ask about the duration of an activity that explains the tiredness now, so we prefer the present perfect continuous.

set2.title: Present Perfect Simple vs Continuous – Set 2
set2.summary: Use present perfect simple for completed results and stative verbs; use present perfect continuous for duration and recent visible effects.

questions.question:
1. Fill in the blank (duration)
We ____ (look) for a new flat for months.
questions.explanation: We focus on how long the search has been going on, so we use the present perfect continuous.

questions.question:
2. Fill in the blank (how many – simple)
He ____ (send) ten job applications this week.
questions.explanation: We focus on the number of completed actions, so we use the present perfect simple.

questions.question:
3. Fill in the blank (stative – simple)
She ____ (have) that car since 2020.
questions.explanation: 'Have' (possession) is stative; we use the present perfect simple.

questions.question:
4. Fill in the blank (recent effect – continuous)
Why are you out of breath? ____ you ____ (exercise)?
questions.explanation: We explain a visible present effect (out of breath) with a recent activity, so we use the present perfect continuous.

questions.question:
5. Multiple choice
I ____ three chapters of the book. I'll finish it tonight.
questions.explanation: We focus on completion (how much is done), so we use the present perfect simple.

questions.question:
6. Multiple choice
They're tired because they ____ all day.
questions.explanation: We explain why they're tired now (duration of activity), so we use the present perfect continuous.

questions.question:
7. Error correction
Wrong: 'I have been having this phone for two years.' Correct the sentence.
answers: i have had this phone for two years
i have had this phone for two years.
I have had this phone for two years
I have had this phone for two years.
questions.explanation: 'Have' (possession) is stative; we use the present perfect simple, not the continuous.

questions.question:
8. Choose the best sentence
Your friend's hands are covered in flour.
questions.explanation: We explain a visible effect (flour on hands) with a recent ongoing activity, so the present perfect continuous is more natural.

set3.title: Present Perfect Simple vs Continuous – Set 3
set3.summary: Duration and visible effect → continuous. Completion and count → simple. Stative verbs → simple only.

questions.question:
1. Fill in the blank (duration)

questions.explanation: We focus on how long she has been studying, so we use the present perfect continuous.

questions.question:
2. Fill in the blank (how many – simple)
I ____ (watch) four episodes of that series today.
questions.explanation: We focus on the number of completed episodes, so we use the present perfect simple.

questions.question:
3. Fill in the blank (stative – simple)
We ____ (believe) in recycling for years.
questions.explanation: 'Believe' is stative; we use the present perfect simple.

questions.question:
4. Multiple choice
Look at the mess! What ____ you ____?
questions.explanation: We explain a visible effect (the mess) with a recent activity, so we use the present perfect continuous.

questions.question:
5. Multiple choice
I ____ five emails so far. I'll do the rest after lunch.
questions.explanation: We focus on how many completed, so we use the present perfect simple.

questions.question:
6. Error correction
Wrong: 'She has been owning that shop since 2019.' Correct the sentence.
answers: she has owned that shop since 2019
she has owned that shop since 2019.
She has owned that shop since 2019
She has owned that shop since 2019.
questions.explanation: 'Own' is stative; we use the present perfect simple, not the continuous.

set4.title: Present Perfect Simple vs Continuous – Set 4
set4.summary: Use simple for results and stative verbs; use continuous for duration and recent visible effects.

questions.question:
1. Fill in the blank (duration)
They ____ (try) to sell their house for six months.
questions.explanation: We focus on how long the activity has been going on, so we use the present perfect continuous.

questions.question:
2. Fill in the blank (completion – simple)
She ____ (already / finish) her homework.
questions.explanation: We focus on completion, so we use the present perfect simple.

questions.question:
3. Fill in the blank (stative – simple)
I ____ (like) that band since their first album.
questions.explanation: 'Like' is stative; we use the present perfect simple.

questions.question:
4. Fill in the blank (negative, recent effect)
She's not answering. She ____ (not feel) well lately.
questions.explanation: We describe an ongoing situation lately with a present effect, so we use the present perfect continuous.

questions.question:
5. Multiple choice
How many times ____ you ____ to Japan?
questions.explanation: We ask about the number of completed visits (experience), so we use the present perfect simple.

questions.question:
6. Choose the best sentence
Your colleague's eyes are red. He looks tired.
questions.explanation: We explain a visible effect (red eyes, tired) – 'have you been working late?' fits the context; continuous for recent ongoing activity.

set1.summary: Past simple for finished past time; present perfect for result now or life experience.

2. She ____ (live) here since 2019.
questions.explanation: Since + duration up to now → present perfect.

4. They ____ (leave) an hour ago.
5. I'm not hungry. I ____ already ____ lunch.
6. When ____ you ____ to Paris?

answers: I went to the cinema yesterday.

set1.title: Prepositions – Simple (time and place)
set1.summary: Gap fill: time (at, on, in, for, since) and place (at, on, in, to).

questions.question: 1. I get up ____ 7 o'clock every day.
questions.explanation: We use **at** with exact clock times (at 7 o'clock, at noon, at midnight). Use **on** for days (on Monday) and **in** for longer periods (in 1995, in summer).

questions.question: 2. The meeting is ____ Monday.
questions.explanation: We use **on** with days of the week and dates (on Monday, on 5th March). Use **at** for clock times and **in** for months, years or seasons.

questions.question: 3. She was born ____ 1995.
questions.explanation: We use **in** with years, months and seasons (in 1995, in January, in summer). Use **on** for specific days and **at** for clock times.

questions.question: 4. The book is ____ the table.
questions.explanation: We use **on** when something is on top of a surface (on the table, on the wall, on the floor). Use **in** for inside a space and **at** for a point or place as a meeting point.

questions.question: 5. He lives ____ London.
questions.explanation: We use **in** with cities, countries and enclosed or large areas (in London, in the box, in the room). Use **at** for a specific point (at the station) and **on** for a street or surface.

questions.question: 6. We'll meet ____ the bus stop.
questions.explanation: We use **at** for a specific point or place where something happens (at the bus stop, at the door, at home). Use **in** for being inside a building or area.

questions.question: 7. I'm going ____ the supermarket.
questions.explanation: We use **to** for movement or direction towards a place (to the supermarket, to school, to work). Use **at** when we are already there (at the supermarket).

questions.question: 8. She's been waiting ____ two hours.
questions.explanation: We use **for** to say how long something lasts (for two hours, for a week). Use **since** when we say when it started (since 9 o'clock) and **during** when we say when it happened (during the meeting).

questions.question: 9. I've lived here ____ 2020.
questions.explanation: We use **since** with a point in time when something started and is still true (since 2020, since Monday). Use **for** with a duration (for three years) and **from** when we don't imply 'until now'.

questions.question: 10. The keys are ____ the drawer.
questions.explanation: We use **in** when something is inside a space (in the drawer, in the box, in the room). Use **on** for on top of a surface and **under** for underneath.

questions.question: 11. I'll see you ____ the morning.
questions.explanation: We use **in** with parts of the day (in the morning, in the afternoon) but **at** for night (at night).

questions.question: 12. The shop opens ____ 9 am.
questions.explanation: Exact time → at (at 9 am, at noon).

questions.question: 13. She was born ____ 15th March.
questions.explanation: Specific date → on (on 15th March, on Monday).

questions.question: 14. We're going on holiday ____ August.
15. The pen is ____ the desk.
questions.explanation: On top of a surface → on.

questions.question: 16. They live ____ the end of the street.
questions.explanation: A specific point (end of the street) → at.

questions.question: 17. I've been learning English ____ six months.
18. We stayed ____ midnight.
questions.explanation: Up to a time → until or till.

questions.question: 19. The answer is ____ the bottom of the page.
questions.explanation: A specific point (bottom of the page) → at.

set2.title: Prepositions – Advanced
set2.summary: Gap fill: by, through, beside, between, during, under, across, along, by (transport).

questions.question: 1. The project must be finished ____ Friday.
questions.explanation: We use **by** to mean 'no later than' or 'before' a time (by Friday, by 5 pm). Use **until** when something continues up to that time (wait until Friday), and **on** for the day itself (on Friday).

questions.question: 2. We walked right ____ the park from one side to the other to reach the station.
questions.explanation: We use **through** when we move from one side of an area or space to the other (through the park, through the tunnel). Use **across** for a surface (across the road) and **along** for following a line (along the path).

questions.question: 3. She sat right ____ me in the cinema so we could share the popcorn.
questions.explanation: We use **beside** or **next to** when one thing is at the side of another (beside me, next to the window). Use **between** for something in the middle of two others (between you and me).

questions.question: 4. Divide the sweets ____ the four children.
questions.explanation: We use **between** when we talk about two or more separate people or things (between the four children, between A and B). Use **among** for a general group when we don't name them individually (among the crowd).

questions.question: 5. I'll be there ____ 9 and 10 o'clock.
questions.explanation: We use **between** for a time (or place) in the middle of two points (between 9 and 10, between Monday and Friday). Use **from...to** for a range (from 9 to 10).

questions.question: 6. We discussed the problem ____ the meeting.
questions.explanation: We use **during** when something happens within a period or event (during the meeting, during the film). Use **for** for how long (for two hours) and **while** with a clause (while we were meeting).

questions.question: 7. The cat is hiding ____ the sofa—you can see its tail sticking out from underneath.
questions.explanation: We use **under** when something is below or beneath another thing (under the sofa, under the table). Use **below** for a lower level and **over** for above.

questions.question: 8. They walked ____ the bridge.
questions.explanation: We use **across** when we go from one side of a surface or area to the other (across the bridge, across the road). Use **through** for going inside something (through the tunnel) and **along** for following the length (along the bridge).

questions.question: 9. We drove ____ the coast for miles, following the shoreline.
questions.explanation: We use **along** when we follow a line or length (along the coast, along the river, along the road). Use **through** for from one end to the other inside something, and **across** for from one side to the other.

questions.question: 10. He arrived ____ train.
questions.explanation: We use **by** with means of transport when we say how we travel (by train, by car, by plane). Use **on** for some transport (on foot, on the bus) and **in** for others (in a car, in a taxi).

questions.question: 11. The ball rolled ____ the table and onto the floor.
questions.explanation: Off = from on top of something down or away (off the table).

questions.question: 12. We cycled ____ the river for about five miles.
13. The tunnel goes ____ the mountain.
questions.explanation: From one side to the other inside something → through.

questions.question: 14. She stood ____ the window, looking out.
questions.explanation: At the side of → by, beside, or next to.

questions.question: 15. The deadline is ____ the end of the week.
16. We had a break ____ the journey.
questions.explanation: Within the time of the journey → during.

questions.question: 17. The temperature dropped ____ zero.
18. They ran ____ the road to the other side.
questions.explanation: From one side of a surface to the other → across.

set3.title: Prepositions – Tricky and idiomatic
set3.summary: Gap fill: interested in, good at, look for, depend on, afraid of, tired of, insist on, complain about, focus on, by (agent).

questions.question: 1. I'm interested ____ learning Spanish.
questions.explanation: The fixed phrase is **interested in** (interested in music, interested in learning). We don't use 'interested about' or 'interested on' – it's always **in**.

questions.question: 2. She's good ____ maths.
questions.explanation: We say **good at** a subject or skill (good at maths, good at swimming). Use **good with** for people or tools (good with children) and **good for** when something benefits (good for you).

questions.question: 3. We're looking ____ our keys.
questions.explanation: **Look for** means to search for or try to find (looking for our keys, look for a job). Use **look at** when we look in a direction, and **look after** for taking care of.

questions.question: 4. It depends ____ the weather.
questions.explanation: The fixed phrase is **depend on** (it depends on the weather, it depends on you). We always use **on** after 'depend', not 'of' or 'from'.

questions.question: 5. He's afraid ____ spiders.
questions.explanation: We say **afraid of** (afraid of spiders, afraid of the dark). Use **of** after 'afraid' when we name what we fear; we can also say 'afraid to' do something.

questions.question: 6. I'm tired ____ waiting.
questions.explanation: We say **tired of** when we've had enough of something (tired of waiting, tired of this weather). Use **tired from** when we're physically tired because of something (tired from work).

questions.question: 7. She insisted ____ paying the bill.
questions.explanation: The fixed phrase is **insist on** (insist on paying, insist on coming). We use **on** after 'insist' when we say what someone insists on doing or having.

questions.question: 8. They complained ____ the noise.
questions.explanation: We say **complain about** something (complain about the noise, complain about the service). We can also say **complain to** someone (complain to the manager).

questions.question: 9. We need to focus ____ the main point.
questions.explanation: We say **focus on** something (focus on the main point, focus on your work). Use **on** after 'focus' – we don't say 'focus in' or 'focus at'.

questions.question: 10. The book was written ____ a famous author.
questions.explanation: In passive sentences we use **by** to introduce the person or thing that does the action (written by a famous author, made by hand). Use **by** for the agent, not 'from'.

set1.title: Relative pronouns – Choose the pronoun
set1.summary: Gap fill: which/that for things, who/that for people, where for places, when for time, whose for possession. Avoid 'what' after a noun.

questions.question: 1. The book ____ I'm reading is by a Czech author.
questions.explanation: For things we use **that** or **which**, not **what**.

questions.question: 2. The woman ____ lives next door is very kind.
3. This is the house ____ I was born.
questions.explanation: For place we use **where** (or 'that/which I was born in').

questions.question: 4. The man ____ I spoke to was the manager.
5. I don't remember the day ____ we first met.
questions.explanation: For time we use **when** or **that**, not **what**.

questions.question: 6. The film ____ we saw yesterday was boring.
questions.explanation: For things we use **that** or **which**, never **what** after a noun.

questions.question: 7. The person ____ phone was stolen called the police.

9. The teacher ____ taught us English has retired.

set2.title: Relative pronouns – Correct the error (Czech-style)
set2.summary: Correct sentences that wrongly use 'what' as a relative pronoun. Use which/that, who/that, where, when, why instead.

questions.question: 1. Wrong: The book what I read was very long. Correct the sentence.
answers: The book that I read was very long.
The book which I read was very long.
The book that I read was very long
The book which I read was very long

set1.title: Reported speech – Gap fill
set1.summary: Turn direct speech into reported speech: backshift tenses, change pronouns and time words.

questions.question: 1. "I am tired." → She said she _____ tired.
2. "We will help." → They said they _____ help.
3. "Where do you live?" → He asked me where I _____.
questions.explanation: Reported question: statement order; present → past.

questions.question: 4. "I have seen the film." → She said she _____ seen the film.
questions.explanation: Present perfect → past perfect: had seen.

questions.question: 5. "Close the door." → He _____ me to close the door.
6. "I can swim." → He said he _____ swim.
7. "What is your name?" → She asked (me) what my name _____.
questions.explanation: Reported question: what my name was (statement order).

questions.question: 8. "I saw her yesterday." → He said he had seen her _____.
questions.explanation: Yesterday → the day before in reported speech.

questions.question: 9. "Are you ready?" → He asked me _____ I was ready.
questions.explanation: Yes/No reported: if or whether + statement order.

questions.question: 10. "I must go now." → She said she _____ to go then.

set2.title: Reported speech – Error correction
set2.summary: Correct common mistakes: backshift, say/tell, reported question word order, tell + person + to.

questions.question: 1. Wrong: 'She said she is tired.' (reporting past words) Correct the sentence.
questions.explanation: Backshift: is → was when reporting in the past.

questions.question: 2. Wrong: 'He asked where do I live.' Correct the sentence.
questions.explanation: Reported question: statement order (where I lived).

questions.question: 3. Wrong: 'She told that she would come.' Correct the sentence.
answers: She told me that she would come.
She said that she would come.
She told me that she would come
She said that she would come
questions.explanation: Tell needs a person: tell me. Or use said (that).

questions.question: 4. Wrong: 'He said me to close the door.' Correct the sentence.
answers: He told me to close the door.
He told me to close the door
questions.explanation: Commands use tell + person + to-infinitive, not say.

questions.question: 5. Wrong: 'She said she has finished.' (reporting past words) Correct the sentence.
questions.explanation: Present perfect → past perfect: had finished.

questions.question: 6. Wrong: 'He asked if am I coming.' Correct the sentence.
answers: He asked if I was coming.
He asked if I was coming
questions.explanation: Yes/No reported: if + statement order (if I was coming).

questions.question: 7. Wrong: 'She said to me that she will help.' (reporting past words) Correct the sentence.
answers: She said to me that she would help.
She told me that she would help.
She said to me that she would help
She told me that she would help
questions.explanation: Will → would when reporting in the past.

questions.question: 8. Wrong: 'They asked what time is it.' Correct the sentence.
answers: They asked what time it was.
They asked what time it was
questions.explanation: Reported question: statement order (what time it was).

set1.title: Conditionals – Gap fill
set1.summary: Zero: present + present. First: if + present, will. Second: if + past, would. Third: if + past perfect, would have.

questions.question: 1. Zero: If you heat ice, it _____.
questions.explanation: Zero conditional: present + present for facts.

questions.question: 2. First: If it _____ tomorrow, we will stay at home.
questions.explanation: First: if + present (rains), will in main clause.

questions.question: 3. Second: If I _____ more time, I would help you.
4. Second: If I were you, I _____ (apologise).
questions.explanation: Second: would + base in main clause.

questions.question: 5. Third: If I _____ (know), I would have told you.
6. Third: If she had left earlier, she _____ (catch) the train.
questions.explanation: Third: would have + past participle in main clause.

questions.question: 7. First: If you _____ early, call me.
questions.explanation: First: if + present; main clause can be imperative.

questions.question: 8. Zero: If you don't sleep well, you _____ tired.
9. Second: If we _____ (win) the lottery, we would travel the world.
10. Third: If they hadn't missed the flight, they _____ (arrive) on time.

set2.title: Conditionals – Error correction
set2.summary: Fix common mistakes: no will/would in if-clause; first/second/third form.

questions.question: 1. Wrong: 'If I will see him, I'll tell him.' Correct the sentence.
answers: If I see him, I'll tell him.
If I see him, I'll tell him
questions.explanation: First conditional: no 'will' in the if-clause; use present.

questions.question: 2. Wrong: 'If I would have time, I would help.' Correct the sentence.
answers: If I had time, I would help.
If I had time, I would help
questions.explanation: Second conditional: if-clause uses past simple (had), not would have.

questions.question: 3. Wrong: 'If I would have known, I would have come.' Correct the sentence.
answers: If I had known, I would have come.
If I had known, I would have come
questions.explanation: Third conditional: if-clause uses past perfect (had known), not would have.

questions.question: 4. Wrong: 'If I had known, I would tell you.' (Meaning: I didn't know, so I didn't tell.) Correct the sentence.
answers: If I had known, I would have told you.
If I had known, I would have told you
questions.explanation: Third conditional: would have told for unreal past.

questions.question: 5. Wrong: 'If it will rain, we will stay at home.' Correct the sentence.
answers: If it rains, we will stay at home.
If it rains, we will stay at home
questions.explanation: First conditional: present in if-clause (if it rains).

questions.question: 6. Wrong: 'If she had left earlier, she would catch the train.' Correct the sentence.
answers: If she had left earlier, she would have caught the train.
If she had left earlier, she would have caught the train
questions.explanation: Third conditional: main clause needs would have + past participle.

questions.question: 7. Wrong: 'If you heat water to 100°C, it will boil.' (General fact.) Correct to zero conditional.
answers: If you heat water to 100°C, it boils.
If you heat water to 100°C, it boils
questions.explanation: Zero conditional for general truth: present + present (it boils).

questions.question: 8. Wrong: 'If he would try harder, he could pass.' Correct the sentence.
answers: If he tried harder, he could pass.
If he tried harder, he could pass
questions.explanation: Second conditional: if-clause uses past simple (tried), not would try.
